questions.text: Using only the definition in (a), prove that if \(f\) is differentiable at \(a\), then \(f\) is continuous at \(a\).
(Linearity) Suppose \(f\) and \(g\) are differentiable at \(a\) and \((\alpha,\beta)\in\mathbb{R}^2\). Prove \(((\alpha f+\beta g))'(a)=\alpha f'(a)+\beta g'(a)\) using the definition.
(Product rule from first principles) If \(f\) and \(g\) are differentiable at \(a\), prove \((fg)'(a)=f'(a)g(a)+f(a)g'(a)\) directly from the limit definition.
(Non-differentiability example) Use the definition to determine whether \(h(x)=|x|\) is differentiable at \(a=0\).

answers.text: \(f'(a)=\lim_{h\to 0}\dfrac{f(a+h)-f(a)}{h}\) (if this limit exists as a finite real number).

Write \(f(a+h)-f(a)=\dfrac{f(a+h)-f(a)}{h}\cdot h\). As \(h\to 0\), \((f(a+h)-f(a))/h\to f'(a)\) (finite) and \(h\to 0\), so the product \to 0. Hence \(f(a+h)\to f(a)\); thus \(f\) is continuous at \(a\).

With \(P(x)=f(x)g(x)\), \(
\dfrac{P(a+h)-P(a)}{h}=\dfrac{f(a+h)g(a+h)-f(a)g(a)}{h}
=\dfrac{f(a+h)[g(a+h)-g(a)]}{h}+g(a)\dfrac{f(a+h)-f(a)}{h}.
\) Taking limits and using continuity of \(f,g\) at \(a\) (from part (b)) gives \(f(a)g'(a)+g(a)f'(a)\). Thus \((fg)'(a)=f'(a)g(a)+f(a)g'(a)\).
